@chicago_denise @ctaaction We're sorry you were late. If your bus was going slow, it might have been to avoid running ahead of schedule. Avoiding "running hot" is a way we and other agencies work to prevent bus bunching & long waits: https://t.co/IJBYXIozCN
@gisellebassxo We're sorry to hear you encountered this. Please contact our Customer Service department with details (bus # or route/stop/direction/time) so we can fix it: https://t.co/oBpWShjKxn
@BBGLIVE2 If you see someone smoking on a train or bus, please let CTA staff and security guards know. ¬†We‚Äôll continue to work to address as quickly as possible.

@BBGLIVE2 With 2,000+ train trips and 19,000 bus trips daily, it is impossible for us to stop every single instance of smoking on CTA. But by continuing to enforce this basic rule, we hope to improve the travel environment as much as possible.

@NathanLeeOlson @shelb_a_delb In some cases, you may see a bus disappear from listings because it was removed from service or was diverted along an unexpected path. We're working to minimize how often this happens. More info: https://t.co/ACG59yYgIk

@Silvertower7 @streetsblogchi @TransitCenter @activetrans @RTA_Chicago The letters are merely unique, easy to remember labels. The area map or staff as you exit a station can point you to stop "E" for the specific bus you need, for ex, and then when you walk outside it's a nice visible symbol to be able to spot and walk toward even if across street.

@CallYouOut2023 We're sorry this has been your experience. If the heat isn't working or not working well enough, please let the operator know. They can't troubleshoot it on the bus, but they can report it to the garage for repair.

@shelb_a_delb We're sorry this happened to you. If a real-time arrival prediction gets "stuck," it's likely because the bus was actually unexpectedly stuck for some reason: detour, traffic incident, equipment problem, etc. We know how disruptive this can be and work to mitigate it.

Buses are equipped with engine pre-heaters that circulate coolants through bus engines in cold weather so motors can be started up easily and interiors of the buses can be warmed quickly. This also reduces emissions and results in fuel cost savings. https://t.co/Y0uPWW3JQw

Winter weather can be challenging for Chicagoans-especially when you need to get somewhere!

To ensure our riders get from Points A to B safely & comfortably, we've developed strategies to address snow, ice & subzero temps, all of which can impact bus & rail service. üîΩ https://t.co/TCHsqQyXiB

@MKinChiTown The Operator can turn the air on, typically this happens when the bus is started, however they cannot adjust, fix or troubleshoot it. Unlike trains, there isn't a "reset" switch. If it's not working well, please let them know so that it's reported/taken to the garage for repair.

The bus boycott ended with the November 1956 Supreme Court ruling that segregation on public buses was unconstitutional.
 
At CTA we continue in the legacy of Dr. King by advocating and providing transit equity for the city of Chicago.

Martin Luther King, Jr. led the Montgomery Bus Boycott for 381 days in 1955-56, which ignited when Rosa Parks was arrested for refusing to give up her seat on a bus for white passengers. https://t.co/pAveFRRfxd

@WellToldStories We apologize for the disruption & delays. Altho we do pull buses off of regular routes to help populate the impromptu bus shuttle service, we cannot pull all of them off or it would totally shut down the other bus routes--it is a tricky balancing act. We appreciate your patience.
